S3.E1.table: A(n+1)=f(𝐗(n−m+1:n))A(n+1)=f\left(\mathbf{X}(n-m+1:n)\right)italic_A ( italic_n + 1 ) = italic_f ( bold_X ( italic_n - italic_m + 1 : italic_n ) ) (1)
references: Sequence Length Setting: In determining the optimal sequence length for our model, we conducted a thorough review of existing literature in the field. Based on findings from relevant studies[16][47][51], we set the parameter mùëömitalic_m in Equation 1 to 4, meaning that the prediction of the next app usage is based on the information related to the most recent four apps used by the user.

S3.T1.1.caption: TABLE I: Examples of dataset.
references: Our study employs a real-world application usage dataset collected from Shanghai, China, during a week-long period from April 20 to April 26, 2016 [53]. Each dataset entry contains an anonymous user ID, a timestamp, a base station ID, and the ID of the app being used, organized chronologically by timestamp. Table I provides a comprehensive view of the dataset format, featuring five sequential records from a single user for illustrative purposes.

Moreover, every base station in the dataset is designated by a unique ID and corresponds to a 17-dimensional Points of Interest (POI) vector. These POI vectors reflect the socioeconomic activities characteristic of the areas around the base stations, encompassing categories such as Medical care, Hotels, and Business affairs. In our analysis, POI data plays a crucial role in enhancing the prediction of app usage patterns. Table II displays the POIs linked to the three base stations mentioned in Table I, providing insight into the local functionalities and services available in their vicinity.

S4.T3.1.table:
Method Year Data Fusion Method Applicability and Limitations of Data Fusion
NAP[50]
DeepApp[16]
PAULCI[51] Appl. Sci 2020
ACM TIST 2020
Comput Commun 2022 Heterogeneous raw data is directly concatenated and subsequently encoded, followed by additional operations. • Simple, efficient, and straightforward implementation. • Overlooks the complexity of data relationships and relevance. • Prone to information overload with minimal insights. • Scalability issues hinder performance in complex analyses.
AppUsage2Vec[47] ICDE 2019 Integrates user and app data through a Hadamard product, aiming to capture the intricate interactions between user behavior and app usage patterns. • Directly captures interactions between user behavior and app usage. • Element-wise multiplication may overlook complex data interactions. • Fails to account for dynamic user preference changes. • Dimensionality constraints necessitate additional preprocessing. • Scalability challenges impact computational efficiency.
DUGN[49] IEEE TMC 2023 Utilizes an Interest Fusion Layer to capture the dynamic evolution of user preferences. • Adapts to real-time, evolving user interests for personalized recommendations. • Difficulties in managing interest changes without adding noise. • Requires advanced techniques to distinguish between transient and enduring interest changes. • Balancing evolving and current interests is challenging, risking recommendations becoming static or erratic. • Dependence on singular data mode may lead to incomplete user profiles.
S4.T3.1.caption: TABLE III: Detailed Comparison of Data Fusion Methods for Mobile App Prediction
footnotes:
[50]

G. S. Moreira, H. Jo, and J. Jeong, ‚ÄúNap: Natural app processing for predictive user contexts in mobile smartphones,‚Äù Applied Sciences, vol. 10, no. 19, p. 6657, 2020.

[16]

T. Xia, Y. Li, J. Feng, D. Jin, Q. Zhang, H. Luo, and Q. Liao, ‚ÄúDeepapp: Predicting personalized smartphone app usage via context-aware multi-task learning,‚Äù ACM Transactions on Intelligent Systems and Technology (TIST), vol. 11, no. 6, pp. 1‚Äì12, 2020.

[51]

A. Solomon, B. Shapira, and L. Rokach, ‚ÄúPredicting application usage based on latent contextual information,‚Äù Computer Communications, vol. 192, pp. 197‚Äì209, 2022.

[47]

S. Zhao, Z. Luo, Z. Jiang, H. Wang, F. Xu, S. Li, J. Yin, and G. Pan, ‚ÄúAppusage2vec: Modeling smartphone app usage for prediction,‚Äù in 2019 IEEE 35th International Conference on Data Engineering (ICDE).   IEEE, 2019, pp. 1322‚Äì1333.

[49]

Y. Ouyang, B. Guo, Q. Wang, Y. Liang, and Z. Yu, ‚ÄúLearning dynamic app usage graph for next mobile app recommendation,‚Äù IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, 2022.
references: In the pursuit of advancing mobile app prediction, our comprehensive review of existing data fusion methods revealed limitations in their capacity to integrate multi-modal data effectively and to discern the importance of varying data types (as shown in Table III). To address these shortcomings and enhance predictive performance, we propose a series of strategic improvements: emphasizing context relevance, delineating the importance of data modalities, adopting cross-modal attention mechanisms, and implementing progressive fusion strategies. These improvements have culminated in the development of the Multi-Modal Data Progressive Fusion Module, a novel approach designed to navigate the challenges identified.

S4.T4.1.table:
Method Year Feature Extraction Method Applicability and Limitations of Feature Extraction
NAP[50] Appl. Sci 2020 LSTMs. • Excel at handling sequential data. • Fall short in processing multimodal data, missing complex interactions. • The linear approach of LSTMs struggles to adapt to dynamic relevancies and changes in application importance within sequences.
DeepApp[16] ACM TIST 2020 Uses multiple GRUs to analyze concatenated data, aiming to understand time patterns and user behavior. • More efficient and use fewer resources than LSTMs for sequential predictions. • Struggle with capturing deep temporal dependencies in certain scenarios. • Prone to overlooking critical spatiotemporal interaction features.
PAULCI[51] Comput Commun 2022 Combines GRU networks with an Attention Layer to selectively focus on the most informative parts of the data sequence, enhancing prediction accuracy. • Simple and straightforward, easy to deploy and optimize. • Applying attention mechanisms too simplistically misses key features in complex multimodal inputs. • The fixed structure hampers adjustments or improvements for new requirements.
AppUsage2Vec[47] ICDE 2019 Dual Deep Neural Networks (Dual-DNNs) employ two separate DNNs to independently extract user and application features before merging them. • Allows for specialized processing of user and application data. • May overlook complex multimodal interactions, leading to potential loss of context and inefficiency. • Dual-DNNs are modular but lack adaptability.
DUGN[49] IEEE TMC 2023 Utilizes a combination of temporal gating mechanisms, hierarchical graph attention networks, and self-attention mechanisms to deeply understand user interests and their evolution. • Effectively captures user preferences. • Performance relies on data quality. • Adaptability is limited by fixed structure. • Ignoring multimodal data can reduce accuracy.
S4.T4.1.caption: TABLE IV: Detailed Comparison of Feature Extraction Methods for Mobile App Prediction
footnotes:
[50]

G. S. Moreira, H. Jo, and J. Jeong, ‚ÄúNap: Natural app processing for predictive user contexts in mobile smartphones,‚Äù Applied Sciences, vol. 10, no. 19, p. 6657, 2020.

[16]

T. Xia, Y. Li, J. Feng, D. Jin, Q. Zhang, H. Luo, and Q. Liao, ‚ÄúDeepapp: Predicting personalized smartphone app usage via context-aware multi-task learning,‚Äù ACM Transactions on Intelligent Systems and Technology (TIST), vol. 11, no. 6, pp. 1‚Äì12, 2020.

[51]

A. Solomon, B. Shapira, and L. Rokach, ‚ÄúPredicting application usage based on latent contextual information,‚Äù Computer Communications, vol. 192, pp. 197‚Äì209, 2022.

[47]

S. Zhao, Z. Luo, Z. Jiang, H. Wang, F. Xu, S. Li, J. Yin, and G. Pan, ‚ÄúAppusage2vec: Modeling smartphone app usage for prediction,‚Äù in 2019 IEEE 35th International Conference on Data Engineering (ICDE).   IEEE, 2019, pp. 1322‚Äì1333.

[49]

Y. Ouyang, B. Guo, Q. Wang, Y. Liang, and Z. Yu, ‚ÄúLearning dynamic app usage graph for next mobile app recommendation,‚Äù IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, 2022.
references: After conducting an in-depth analysis of existing feature extraction methods for mobile application data (as shown in Table IV), we identified limitations in their ability to maintain the richness of information in complex data environments and a lack of flexibility to adapt to new data types or evolving tasks. These limitations hindered the models‚Äô ability to capture subtle relationships within the data, thereby constraining their predictive capabilities. To overcome these challenges and enhance predictive performance, we proposed a series of improvements, including adopting an Encoder-Decoder architecture to extract features that reflect the complex relationships within the data, introducing attention mechanisms to prioritize important features while reducing noise, and designing modular and replaceable feature extraction methods to improve model performance and adaptability. Leveraging these enhancements, we crafted an Feature Extraction Module as depicted in the yellow segment of Figure 3, adeptly tackling the previously mentioned challenges.

references: Under the premise that all basic prediction models adopt Appformer, we conducted a comparative experiment to contrast the improved time encoding and fusion methods with the basic time encoding and addition method T1subscriptT1\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{1}}roman_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT[60]. As shown in Table VIII, the experimental results clearly demonstrate that our proposed improved method outperforms the basic method across various metrics. This indicates that our method accurately captures the inherent patterns of time information, enabling the model to better understand the changes in users‚Äô app usage habits over time, thereby enhancing prediction accuracy and stability.

references: We conducted ablation experiments specifically on the input to the Decoder, with the results presented in Table IX. The optimal results were obtained when only POI data was input into the Decoder. This is because the user sequence itself consists of repetitive numbers, and the time series changes slowly. The presence of redundant data could potentially interfere with the Decoder‚Äôs decoding operation. Hence, we consider AKT (Decoder(l)) as our optimal result. The Appformer + K + T mentioned in previous experiments refers to this AKT (Decoder(l)).

S6.T11.1.caption: TABLE XI: Results of clustering experiments with different cluster sizes.
references: The experimental results in Tables XI and XII are supplemented by the visualizations in Figures 6 and 6. The outcomes in Tables XI and XII demonstrate that the optimal number of clusters for POI data, based on Hit@1, Hit@3, Hit@5, MRR, and F1 score, is 5. However, the relationship between the number of clusters and performance is not simply linear. As shown in Figure 6, performance generally declines as the number of clusters increases from 5 to 55, albeit with some fluctuations. Figure 6 provides a more detailed view for cluster sizes 0-10, confirming that performance peaks at 5 clusters.

S6.T13.1.1.caption: TABLE XIII: Results for different clustering methods.
references: Testing different clustering methods: Experimental results, as shown in Table XIII, indicate that when considering three key metrics: Hit@1, MRR, and F1 score, the K-Modes algorithm demonstrates superior performance. To further understand these results, we employed Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to reduce the dimensionality of the POI vectors corresponding to base station IDs and the cluster center vectors obtained by different clustering algorithms down to two dimensions for a detailed visual analysis. The visualization figures are presented from Figures 11, 11, 11, 11, and 11.
